p: Sequencing methods have benefited from the development of PCR, recombinant DNA technologies, discovery and molecular cloning of thermostable sequencing polymerases (e.g., Taq polymerase), and reverse transcriptase, as well as the development of fluorescent dye-labeled ddNTPs and process parallelization, which facilitated the birth of genome projects and the field of metagenomics ( Heather and Chain, 2016, Hutchison, 2007, Kulski, 2016, Mardis, 2013, Schuster, 2008). Initially, laboratory methods of viral metagenomics relied on molecular cloning of amplified genomic fragments coupled with Sanger sequencing of hundreds to thousands of individual clones ( Allander et al., 2005, Finkbeiner et al., 2008). Collectively, the major advantages of this technology are the long read lengths and the excellent resolution of sequence repeats and homopolymer regions. The drawbacks include the limited throughput and the relatively high per base sequencing cost ( Hutchison, 2007, Schuster, 2008).
